GSK announced this morning that they have formally withdrawn from the process relating to Pfizer’s Consumer Healthcare business bid. In a statement, GSK’s CEO reinforced the company’s clear focus on not compromising capital allocation priorities. Our takeaways from this are as follow: (1) We expect this news to provide some comfort to investors who were nervous around the sustainability of the current 80p dividend post 2018. As a reminder, GSK had previously highlighted that they intend to build free cash flow cover of the annual dividend to a target range of 1.25-1.50x before returning dividend to growth. (2) We also believe this reaffirms their priority to kick start the growth outlook for their Pharma business.

BornCynic Has that bit of Pfizer come up with any new products?

Mark Wilson, Group Chief Executive Officer of Aviva plc, said:
“I am very aware that Aviva is in a position of trust with our customers and investors . To maintain that trust it is critical that we listen to and act on feedback. The reputation of Aviva, and the trust people have in us, is paramount. Our announcement today means that preference shareholders can rest secure in their holdings. The Board and I have a duty to consider not just the financial implications of our actions. We must consider the impact to Aviva’s wider reputation. I hope our decision today goes some way to restoring that trust.”

BE11:35am

FY PBT of £726m was in line with the midpoint of guidance at £725m. As expected, the FY dividend was maintained at 158p. Next Brand EBIT was £10m better than expected, offset by lower Sourcing and Other income. Within the divisions, there is a c£15m reallocation from Online to Retail to fully recognise the cost of services offered. The Retail EBIT margin declined 260bp (UBS-280bp) with some extra payroll savings. Online EBIT margin declined 40bp (UBSe 70bp) with lower catalogue costs. Overall, as expected, Retail EBIT fell as a result of Retail operational gearing and additional costs such as clearance and Online opex investment.

Soundbuy Reiss - weren't they gonna float? Or have they?
Stateless @BE I disagree with you on Aviva. For various reasons, but the main one is that Aviva is continually raising new capital from the debt market. It can't afford to annoy the people it expects to keep providing money by acting in a way no one expected. If it did this it would have paid a real penalty on future issuance
BE11:35am

Guidance remains for full price sales growth of -2% to +4%. There is no mention of adverse weather in Q1. We are not sure if this mention Next hopes to catch up later in the year, or that sales weakness has been absorbed by weak comps from Q1 last year. Guidance for Retail is for LFL of -8.5% and another hefty decline of -270bp in the EBIT margin (operational gearing rises as the EBIT margin declines). Online sales are expected to rise over 10% with the EBIT margin up 60bp as the fixed cost base is not expected to rise in line with sales. The midpoint of sales guidance still drives £705m PBT (UBSe £715m).

11:35 am
BE11:36am

The weather and an early Easter are unhelpful and comps get tougher as the year progresses. However, range and service improvements at Next, and the high level of credit profit, offer some protection. As the year progresses there are risk and rewards from higher industry clearance (from the poor start to the season, potential industry space reduction), but long term upside from what could be a significant year of capacity reduction in apparel and homewares.

BE11:36am

(@Stateless: yeah, fair. Agreed.)

BE11:36am

Our PT is based on DCF and assumes 1.5% terminal sales growth, 16% EBIT margin (FY18 18%) and WACC 8.5%, and in unchanged in line with our estimates. Next news is Q1 sales on 10 May.

We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but given that the company has reiterated its guidance range, we think consensus earnings forecasts are unlikely to change very much today. Prior to today, according to Bloomberg, consensus was looking for FY 2018/19 Pre Tax Profits of £706m (give EPS of 409p).
-Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Next is trading on 11.3x Cal 2018 earnings, 8.7x EBITDA with a 3.7% Dividend Yield (including special dividend payments). This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.0x, 7.6x and 4.5% respectively

VV75 Company believes that it could potentially result in a rapid and material loss of market share for Suboxone® Film in the US, an effect that could occur within months of a successful launch of a generic film alternative into the US market.
VV75 still not very favourable now is it?
BE11:48am

Plus, you have considerable uncertainty when around when FDA clearance actually arrives for any of the generics.

Threadneedle BE and of course....Indivior was itself spun out of Reckitts back in 2014......
BE11:48am

11:49 am
BE11:49am

So, while Alvogen's initial victory is a clear setback it doesn't seem to have changed the maths much on when to expect generics to arrive.

wayneJ Bryce is that rare blend of journalist who intuitively grasps numbers. Even knowing how to use Excel puts him in the elite subset of journalists; but also having the common sense to know when a calculation does not feel right and willing to debug Excel. Unbeatable. Indeed I know of no other kilt wearing grumpy wikipedian brained journalist who could even compete.
BE11:51am

And Indivior is of course rushing folk onto Sublocade, its injectable synthetic skag. Reformulations, incremental improvements and defensive legal actions to defend market share have been central to this business from the start.

BornCynic @WayneJ - you do know he's married :)
wayneJ Heck if this was Trustpilot I am sure he would have numerous 5 star reviews.....
nichoman can I give a plug to Robert shrimsley's piece on CA / facebook...v funny...laughter is not permitted in my workplace and struggled to stop myself
BE11:52am

(@wayneJ: my Excel desk licence has expired. I'm relying solely on Google Sheets now.)

11:52 am
BE11:52am

........... so, no big whoop. Here's Stifel.

BE11:53am

Multiple hurdles remain before a generic to Suboxone film can be launched in the US. Since the FDA is yet to approve Alvogen's generic version of Suboxone film, it remains unable to launch the product at present. Even if the FDA were to approve Alvogen's generic, two further hurdles remain. First, Indivior intends to appeal the current ruling, a process that is likely to take a further 12-24 months. If Alvogen were to receive FDA approval of its generic during this process, we believe it is unlikely to launch given this would be an 'at risk' launch and could result in significant damages. Second, Indivior has a further two key patents ('454 and '221) it has asserted against Alvogen, which have yet to go to court. An additional new patent ('305) is also expected to be granted on 3 April 2018. Indivior will again assert this patent against Alvogen. A district court ruling on these three patents will likely take 12-18 months. We see it as highly unlikely that Alvogen will therefore be in a position to launch a generic version of Suboxone film in 2018. We continue to forecast launch of a generic in mid-2019.

Soundbuy @nichoman - usher in a crematorium?
BE11:53am

Reiterate Buy rating. With Sublocade launch ongoing and FDA approval of RBP-7000 in schizophrenia expected in July 2018, we continue to see significant catalysts for long- term value creation at Indivior. Whilst the court ruling in favour of Alvogen clearly means there are now two generics that have navigated Indivior's first line of patent defence, a further three patents remain unchallenged providing a significant hurdle to reaching the market. Based on our forecasts, Indivior trades on a 2018E P/E of 10x which assumes generic competition to Suboxone film in mid-2019. Longer term, we see this differential narrowing as Sublocade replaces Suboxone film as the group's key product.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

And Numis .....

BE11:54am

As it stands, Alvogen does not have FDA approval and would be launching “at-risk” before the appeal plays out, and would therefore be liable for material damages if Indivior prevail on appeal. The Federal Appeal is at best a 50/50 ruling, but with no new evidence being submitted we assume Indivior loses the appeal.

BE11:55am

There is an argument that wider availability of lower cost Suboxone could actually draw more patients into medically assisted treatment, which in turn would expand the immediate addressable market for Sublocade. Sublocade puts the physician back in control of treatment and addresses the key weakness of Suboxone: adherence to treatment on a daily basis is difficult for these patients.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Also buyers.

RAVER Great Bryce thanks for the Indivior

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Smiths is just a straight miss.

Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,421, down 115 (-7.49%), High: 1,444, Low: 1,354, Volume: 3.26m
BE11:59am

H1 poor against consensus, guidance a bit measured.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Medical seems to be the problem, and seems to be requiring some investment.

BE12:00pm

Crane okay, detection no worse than expected, Interconnect in unpleasant markets.

BE12:00pm

Here's RBC.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

H1 FY 2018 sales/EBITA/EPS of £1,549m/£247m/40.4p compared with consensus (Vuma) estimates of £1,589m/£264m/41.7p, so a 3%/6%/7% miss at the ‘headline’ trading level. Underlying (organic) revenue growth was -1% YoY, implying an improvement in Q2 from Q1’s -2%. The improvement in momentum is important and likely to be a focus of the analyst presentation. Full-year guidance has been ‘reaffirmed’; the statement highlights management’s confidence that the Group’s growth rate will accelerate over the balance of the year. It appears that the reference to ‘a return to growth in FY2018’ from the previous outlook has been dropped. This may raise some concerns, although going through the divisional outlooks this appears to be a change of wording rather than a genuine change to the Group outlook. Net debt was £961m, in line with our expectations and suggesting a good performance despite the weaker profits. The results are clearly a little disappointing, however whether consensus sees any meaningful cuts (ex-FX) will largely depend on the confidence in the H2 pickup management can communicate at the analyst presentation.

BE12:01pm

Our view has been and continues to be that we see value in Smiths businesses – the shares trade on 15.9x NTM PER (sector on 16.7x), and 6.5% FCF yield with conservative cash flow assumptions. While further portfolio actions are still possible, we expect that the most likely next catalyst is the delivering on the H2 growth pickup.

BE12:01pm

Just looking at the daily chart, shares off as much as 10% at one point. That feels a bit severe.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Jefferies incoming.

BE12:02pm

1H18 organic sales fell 1% despite a weak 1H18 in Detection, the latter a timing issue. That may encourage some observers – and it would be churlish on our part not to regard it as a step forward. However, even growth in 2H18 may not prove the Group’s strategy is working as end markets are also likely more helpful than for some years. The risk is that the goalposts move so that 2-4% organic growth is perceived as merely adequate rather than transformational.

DJ Mitie upgrade?
BE12:02pm

If the goalposts shift. The Smiths Group valuation is not overtly demanding, in our view. Nonetheless, when we set our PT of 1,575p (see our note of 22 January 2018 – Same, but Different) we could not accept a forecast FY20 dividend yield of under 3%. We recognise the Smiths Excellence System has enhanced FCF and protected margins as investment in R&D rose, but we still believe there must be sustained organic growth in sales. To be clear, we believe Smiths is long overdue some assistance from its major end markets in returning to and sustaining organic sales growth. As we mulled that thought over, we began to wonder if the goalposts might shift in the sense that Smiths would have to be perceived as bettering the growth in its end markets, not just matching it.

12:02 pm
undefined
BE12:03pm

Oh, forgot to flag up this Smurfit story in the Irish Independent.

BE12:03pm

https://www.indepe...l-36734723.htmlThe
